questions.clue: Before becoming a famous playwright, this English bard was part-owner of the Globe Theatre.
This U.S. founding father invented the lightning rod and bifocal glasses.
Known for his theory of relativity, this scientist also played the violin as a means of stress relief.
Before his presidency, this Civil War general had a penchant for painting and created over 30 works.
While known for her nursing during the Crimean War, she was also a statistician who created the 'coxcomb' chart.
This famous French novel by Victor Hugo, featuring Jean Valjean, was translated into English as 'The Miserable Ones'.
Originally written in German, 'Die Verwandlung' by Franz Kafka is more commonly known in English as this.
Translated from Spanish, this work by Gabriel García Márquez is known as 'One Hundred Years of Solitude'.
This Russian novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, originally titled 'Prestupleniye i nakazaniye', is known in English as this.
This Japanese novel by Haruki Murakami, 'Norwegian Wood', is a title that pays homage to a song by this famous band.

categories.name: Innovations in Science from the 20th Century

questions.clue: In 1969, Neil Armstrong was the first human to walk on this celestial body.
This 1928 discovery by Alexander Fleming led to the development of antibiotics.
In 1953, Watson and Crick discovered the double helix structure of this molecule.
Developed in 1947, this invention by Bardeen, Brattain, and Shockley is fundamental to modern electronics.
This theory of general relativity, proposed by Einstein in 1915, revolutionized the understanding of gravity in the 20th century.
This essential Italian cheese, known for its hard texture and sharp flavor, is often used grated over pasta dishes.
Originating from Mexico, this fruit is a key ingredient in guacamole and is known for its creamy texture.
This staple grain, used to make sushi, forms the basis of Japanese cuisine and is known for its short, sticky qualities.
Known for its distinctive flavor and health benefits, this fermented cabbage dish is a staple in Korean cuisine.
This Middle Eastern dip, made from ground sesame seeds and chickpeas, is often served with pita and vegetables.
For 200 points: This black and white bear is famously known for its bamboo diet and is native to China.
For 400 points: These majestic cats, known for their striking orange coats with black stripes, are critically endangered due to habitat loss.
For 600 points: This marine creature, known for its slow movement and algae-covered shell, is threatened by boat collisions and habitat destruction.
For 800 points: Known for its unique horn, this animal is poached for its valuable ivory-like keratin, leading to its endangered status.
For 1000 points: This critically endangered primate, found only in the rainforests of Sumatra, is threatened by deforestation and illegal pet trade.

final.clue: This novel, published in 1851, begins with the line "Call me Ishmael" and explores themes of obsession and revenge.
